Investigation on visible-light photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid in the presence of MoO3/ZnO nanorod composites Sze-Mun Lam Jin-Chung Sin Ahmad Zuhairi Abdullah Abdul Rahman Mohamed ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Engineering Campus, 14300 Nibong Tebal, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +60 45996410; fax: +60 45941013. Graphical abstract Highlights ► MoO3/ZnO nanorods were newly synthesized by a hydrothermal-precipitation method. ► MoO3 showed visible-light absorption ability and a redshift for the composites. ► Highly enhanced visible-light degradation of 2,4-D was realized. ► The composites were efficiently separated charge carriers to form more ·OH radicals. ► A cooperative photocatalytic mechanism for the composites was also discussed. Nanoscaled MoO3 particles loaded on ZnO nanorods (ZnO NRs) were synthesized via a hydrothermal-precipitation method. X-ray diffraction, field emission-scanning electron microscopy, high resolution transmission electron microscopy, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–vis absorption and photoluminescence studies were used to characterize the structures, morphologies and optical properties of the composites. The results showed that pure orthorhombic phase of α-MoO3 nanoparticles with average sizes of 15–21nm were well dispersed on the surface of ZnO NRs. The MoO3/ZnO NR composites also showed high charge separation efficiency and ·OH generation ability as evidenced by their photoluminescence spectra. The photocatalytic studies revealed that the MoO3/ZnO NRs showed superior visible-light degradation rate for herbicide 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) compared with the pure ZnO NRs. Such enhancement might be attributed to the high separation efficiency of photogenerated electron–hole pairs based on the cooperative roles between bi-components of MoO3 and ZnO NRs. The photocatalytic studies also showed that various parameters such as the MoO3 content in the composite, MoO3/ZnO NRs amount, initial 2,4-D concentration and solution pH exerted their individual influence on the 2,4-D degradation. Moreover, the MoO3/ZnO NRs could be easily recovered and reused due to their one-dimensional nanostructural property. Keywords MoO3 ZnO nanorod Composite Visible light photocatalysis 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid 1 Introduction Semiconductor photocatalysis is a promising approach for environmental remediation purposes and garners much consideration [1,2]. Among the semiconductors investigated, zinc oxide (ZnO) has recently receiving attention because of its unique chemical and physical properties, environmental stability, low cost and considerably high photocatalytic activity. Nevertheless, poor quantum yields caused by low separating efficiency of the photogenerated electrons–holes for the single semiconductors seriously impeded the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of the pollutants. Besides, the structure of the ZnO crystal would be destroyed after consecutive use due to the photocorrosion effect [3]. Some research has found that synthesis of one-dimensional (1D) ZnO nanostructures proved to be an effective route to reduce the recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pairs [4,5]. ZnO nanorods, one of the 1D nanomaterials used in variety of fields [6], are often revealed of their suitability in photocatalysis due to their advantages on [7,8]: (1) enlarging the surface area for mass transfer and reactants access during the reactions, (2) maximizing the length–width ratio by making them easily to be recovered after the reactions, and (3) retarding the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes. Thus, rod structured ZnO nanomaterial is a practical and ideal choice to improve the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of the pollutants. However, for the ZnO nanorods, the photocatalytic activity of ZnO with single modification (1M) is still not satisfactory, which can be attributed to short electron–hole pair lifetime. To further improve their photocatalytic activity, ZnO involving double modifications (2M) has attracted much attention [9–11]. Particularly, semiconductor materials coupled with ZnO catalysts have proved to be promising option in preventing electron–hole pair recombination as the coupled semiconductors can act as irreversible electron and/or hole sinks thus helping efficient charge separation and consequently, achieving a higher photocatalytic reaction rate. It also demonstrated that the coupling of semiconductor materials can reduce the band gap and extend the light absorbance range to visible-light region, so as to improve the photocatalytic ability of ZnO under sunlight irradiation [12]. The TiO2/ZnO, CeO2/ZnO, SnO2/ZnO and CdS/ZnO are the different coupled semiconductors that have been successfully fabricated [4,9,13,14]. Furthermore, molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) is an important semiconductor with band gap of ∼2.85eV. It is a promising catalyst for electrochromic, photochromic sensitive materials, gas sensors, cathodes of Li ion batteries and photoelectric devices [15,16]. Hence, constructing a bi-component photocatalytic system composed of ZnO nanorods and MoO3 may be a good strategy to solve the low quantum yield of ZnO, thus resulting in enhanced visible-light photocatalytic performance. However, to the best of our knowledge, there has been no report on the preparation and photocatalytic properties of these kinds of MoO3/ZnO nanorod materials. In this paper, we describe an effective method to synthesize the ZnO nanorods incorporated with MoO3 nanoparticle (MoO3/ZnO NRs). First, the ZnO nanorods (ZnO NRs) were fabricated through the hydrothermal technique. Next, small sized MoO3 nanoparticles with well-dispersed distribution were assembled on the ZnO NRs via precipitation method. The photocatalytic activities of MoO3/ZnO NRs were evaluated with 2,4-dichlorophenolxyacetic acid (2,4-D) as a model contaminant under visible-light irradiation. The aims of the experiment were to study the effects of MoO3 content in MoO3/ZnO NRs, catalyst amount, initial 2,4-D concentration as well as solution pH on the photocatalytic activities of MoO3/ZnO NRs. Moreover, the stability of synthesized MoO3/ZnO NRs was investigated through successive four cycles of experiments. Furthermore, the mechanism of 2,4-D degradation using MoO3/ZnO NRs was discussed on the basis of the photoluminescence emission spectra of electron–hole recombination and active species ·OH, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis procedure All the chemical reagents used in this work including H2O2 (30vol%), (NH4)6Mo6O24·4H2O, NH4OH (25wt% NH3) and ethanol were of analytical grade and purchased from Acros Organics. The detailed synthesis procedure for pure ZnO NRs was as follows: 2.0g of ZnO powder was weighted into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave of 200mL capacity. Subsequently, 150mL of 30vol% H2O2 solution was added in with stirring. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at a temperature of 180°C for 24h and then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. MoO3/ZnO NR composites were prepared by a precipitation method. The typical procedure for the preparation of MoO3/ZnO NR composites was as follows: 1.0g of ZnO NRs was dispersed in 50mL deionized water and the suspensions were ultrasonicated for 30min. Then, a stoichiometric amount of (NH4)6Mo6O24·4H2O in 0.9mL of NH4OH was added to the ZnO suspensions and stirred magnetically for 12h. The as-formed precipitates were filtrated, washed with deionized water and ethanol and dried in air at 60°C for 12h. Finally, the prepared samples were calcined at 400°C for 2h with a heating rate of 2°Cmin−1. 2.2 Characterization The samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern recorded on a Philips PW1820 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at a scan rate of 2°min−1 in the range of 10–80°. The field emission-scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) spectrum were performed on a LEO SUPRA 50VP. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was captured using a Philips CM-12 (The Netherlands) operated at 120keV. The high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image was taken on a Fei Tecnai 20 operated at 200keV. The infrared spectrum was completed with a Thermo scientific Nicolet IS10 Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometer at scanning range from 500 to 4000cm−1. UV–vis spectrum was recorded on a Perkin Elmer Lambda 35 UV-vis spectrophotometer with BaSO4 as a reference. The photoluminescence (PL) measurement was carried out using a Perkin Elmer Lambda S55 spectrofluorometer using a Xe lamp with an excitation wavelength of 325nm at room temperature. 2.3 Photocatalytic tests The photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared MoO3/ZnO NRs were evaluated by the degradation of 2,4-D aqueous solution. The experiments were carried out as follows: 1.00gL−1 of the sample was dispersed in 100mL of 20mgL−1 2,4-D solution in a 250mL beaker. During all experiments, air was bubbled through the solution at a fixed flow rate of 6mLmin−1 using a specular draft tube. The suspensions were continuously stirred with the aid of a magnetic stirrer. The heterogeneous mixture was equilibrated for 1h in the dark. Subsequently, the solution was irradiated under a 55W compact fluorescent lamp (World Lighting, Germany). The average light intensity striking the surface of the reaction solution was about 14,500lx, as measured by a digital luxmeter. This lamp was fixed about 12cm above the reaction solution. At specific time intervals, 2mL of the sample was withdrawn from the system, centrifuged and then the concentration of the 2,4-D at different time intervals was monitored by HPLC (Perkin Elmer Series 200). The HPLC unit consisted of isocratic pumps from Varian with an UV–vis detector. A C18 column (150mm-length×4.6mm-ID×5μm particle size) was used in sample analysis with mixture of acetonitrile, water and acetic acid in the ratio 70:29:1 volumetric ratio. The analysis conditions were 1mLmin−1 liquid flow rate, detector wavelength=280nm and temperature=32°C. In order to determine the reproducibility of the results, at least duplicated runs were carried out for each condition for averaging the results and the experimental error was found to be within ±4%. 2.4 Reusability of catalyst The reusability of MoO3/ZnO NRs was examined by successive four cycles of experiments. The 2,4-D concentration and solution pH were kept constant at 100mL of 20mgL−1 2,4-D and pH 7.04, respectively for each cycle. After 120min irradiation of visible-light, the suspensions were taken from the beaker and centrifuged to remove the bulk solution. The solid catalyst was washed with deionized water for several times and then added to fresh 2,4-D solution for the subsequent run. 2.5 Analysis of hydroxyl (·OH) radical The formation of •OH radicals on the surface of photoirradiated MoO3/ZnO NRs was detected by photoluminescence (PL) technique with terephthalic acid (TA) as a probe molecule. The principle is that TA readily reacts with ·OH to produce highly fluorescent product, 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid (HTA) which shows the PL signal at 425nm. Experimental procedures were similar to the measurement of photocatalytic activity except that 2,4-D aqueous solution was replaced by the 5×10−4 M TA aqueous solution with a concentration of 2×10−3 M NaOH solution. PL spectra of generated HTA were then recorded on a Perkin Elmer Lambda S55 spectrofluorometer. At the intervals of given irradiation time, the reaction solution was used to measure the increase of the PL intensity at 425nm exited by 315nm light. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the pure ZnO NRs and the MoO3/ZnO NR photocatalyts with different loadings of MoO3. Fig. 1a shows that the crystal phase of the ZnO NRs agreed with wurtzite structure (JCPDS file no. 36-1451). From Fig. 1b–d, all the peaks can be indexed to the orthorhombic phase of α-MoO3 except the diffraction peaks of ZnO, which was well matched with the standard from JCPDS file no. 35-0609 [16,17]. The average crystalline sizes of MoO3 were estimated to be 14.1, 15.3, 17.3, 19.6 and 22.1nm accordingly for MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 0.5at%, 1at%, 2at%, 5at% and 10at%, respectively using Scherrer's equation. (1) L = K λ β cos θ B where L is taken as crystalline size, K is a constant equals to 0.89, λ is 1.5406Å, β is the FWHM measured in radians on the 2θ scale, θ B is the Bragg angle for the diffraction peaks. The XRD patterns can illustrate that the as-prepared samples were comprised of two-phase structure of wurtzite ZnO and orthorhombic phase of α-MoO3. Moreover, the XRD peaks belonging to ZnO in the MoO3/ZnO NR composites did not shift compared with the pure ZnO NRs, which can be implied that the Mo did not substitute into the ZnO lattices for the Zn. 3.2 FESEM–EDX and HRTEM images The morphology of the hydrothermally synthesized ZnO NRs was observed by FESEM in Fig. 2a. It can be seen that the ZnO NRs were 600–800nm long and 15–25nm diameter, so the aspect ratio of length to diameter was around 24–40, which belonged to a typical rod-like structure. Also, the synthesized ZnO NRs have a smooth surface with a hexagonal end. The HRTEM image in Fig. 2b obviously confirmed that ZnO NRs grew along the direction of [0001] plane forming a rod-like structure with a typical lattice of 0.26nm. Because the starting materials used in our experiments were only ZnO powder and 30vol% H2O2 aqueous solution and ZnO2 was the sole resulting solid during hydrothermal reaction (Eq. (2)). Nevertheless, the as-prepared ZnO2 NRs were thermally unstable and would thoroughly decompose into ZnO and O2 when subjected to thermal treatment at 180°C for 24h as shown in Eq. (3). (2) ZnO+H2O2 →ZnO2 +H2O (3) 2ZnO2 →2ZnO+O2 With the mixed solution of ammonium molybdenum tetrahydrate and ammonium solution, Mo nanoparticles were uniformly deposited on the surface of the ZnO NRs. These Mo nanoparticles were supposed to nucleate from the defect parts of the ZnO NRs and grow up. The followed calcination at 400°C for 2h made the Mo became MoO3 without changing the morphology of the MoO3 nanoparticles. Fig. 3 shows the typical FESEM of MoO3/ZnO NR composites with different loadings of MoO3. From Fig. 3a–c, it was found that most of nanosized MoO3 particles were distributed on the surface of ZnO NRs. In addition, the amount of MoO3 nanoparticles formed on ZnO NRs varied and more MoO3 nanoparticles surrounded the surface of ZnO NRs with increase of MoO3 loading. TEM images from Fig. 3d–f indicated that the morphology of MoO3/ZnO NR composites can be changed by adjusting the amounts of precursors. Furthermore, these images have demonstrated that MoO3 nanoparticles were attached on the surface of ZnO NRs and MoO3 nanocrystals have dimensions of about 15–21nm, which was coincided by the obtained XRD investigations. The MoO3 compositions in the as-prepared samples were determined using the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis. The EDX results (inset of Fig. 3a–c) were collected from several spots of the decorated composites, which revealed them to be composed of zinc (Zn), oxygen (O) and molybdenum (Mo) trace elements. Elemental carbon (C) detected was originated from the supporting carbon tape. 3.3 FTIR spectra FTIR spectra were also carried out to study the pure ZnO NRs and MoO3/ZnO NR composites. The pure ZnO NRs spectrum (Fig. 4a) was dominated by the band at 542cm−1, which can be ascribed to the stretching of Zn–O bond. Apart from distinctive band of the Zn–O stretching bond, from Fig. 4b–f, FTIR spectra of the coupling composite displayed dominant bands for MoO3 nanoparticles. Concretely, the bands in the region 400–600cm−1 can be assigned to overlapping stretching vibrations of MoO bonds in MoO3 with the stretching mode of ZnO bonds. Moreover, the medium to strong bands at 886cm−1 and 1006cm−1 can be observed with increasing MoO3 loading in the composites. These absorption bands were attributed to the bridging MoO bonds in molybdate species in the MoO3/ZnO NR composites [19,20]. Furthermore, the broad absorption band at 3428cm−1 and a 1645cm−1 band can be corresponded to the OH groups and H2O molecules strongly bound to the catalyst surface [18]. Compared with that in the pure ZnO NRs sample, the intensities of the two absorption bands in MoO3/ZnO NR composites were much stronger. This inferred that the introduction of MoO3 made the catalyst possessed more surfaces OH groups. The OH groups play a pivotal role on the photocatalytic reaction because they can capture the photogenerated holes and then form ·OH radicals with high oxidation capability. 3.4 UV–vis absorption spectra UV–vis absorption spectra of the MoO3/ZnO NR composites along with the pure ZnO NRs were shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that the absorption edges were at the wavelength of about 390–410nm for the pure ZnO NRs and MoO3/ZnO NR composite samples. Comparing with pure ZnO NRs (Fig. 5a), additional broad tails from about 400nm to 600nm appeared in the spectra of the MoO3/ZnO NR composites (as recorded in Fig. 5b–d). The result indicated that the absorption of MoO3/ZnO NR composites was enlarged to the visible spectrum due to the existence of MoO3 that modified the optical absorption edge. With increasing the loading of MoO3 in MoO3/ZnO NRs, the absorption intensities of composites were enhanced. In addition, all the absorption edge of MoO3/ZnO NR composites showed slight redshift. This result might be ascribed to the increase of particle size of MoO3 nanoparticles. Above results revealed that the MoO3/ZnO NR composites can absorb in both UV and visible regions of the solar light. Hence, the absorption property deduced that the MoO3/ZnO NR composites could be promising in visible-light photocatalysis compared with that of pure ZnO NRs. 3.5 Evaluation of photocatalytic activity 3.5.1 The effect of the MoO3 loading on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D To evaluate the photocatalytic activity of as-prepared MoO3/ZnO NR composites, the degradation of herbicide 2,4-D was carried out as a test reaction. 2,4-D was selected as a model contaminant since it was a well known endocrine disruptor and still commonly used because of its low cost and good selectivity [21]. Extensive use and poor biodegradability of 2,4-D have resulted in its ubiquitous presence in the environment and have led to contamination of surface and ground waters [22]. Thus, the use of ZnO photocatalysis as alternative options for the degradation of 2,4-D from water has been explored [23,24]. The photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D over the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at different MoO3 loadings is shown in Fig. 6a. It indicated that the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at% showed the excellent photocatalytic activity, which may be ascribed to the improvement in charge transmission between the semiconductors ZnO NRs and MoO3 prolonged the charge carriers lifetime. Moreover, the photocatalytic performance of the coupled semiconductors was also related to the surface contact between particles, geometry of the particles and particle size. When the proportion of MoO3 was low (0.5at%), the effect of charge separation induced by MoO3 was not obvious because of the insufficiency of MoO3. However, when the concentration of MoO3 increased to 10at%, quite a number of MoO3 nanoparticles would surround some active sites of ZnO NRs and hindered the contact between nanorods and oxygen contained species, which resulted in the decrease of photocatalytic properties [4]. The kinetic profiles of the degradation of 2,4-D under visible-light were also investigated. Fig. 6b depicts the ln(C o /C t ) of 2,4-D versus irradiation time t for different catalysts. The approximate linear relationship of ln(C o /C t ) versus t indicated that the photocatalytic degradation reactions of 2,4-D tend to follow the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) pseudo-first-order kinetics model. Its kinetics may be expressed as follows [25–27]: (4) ln ( C o / C t ) = k o b s t where C o is the equilibrium molar concentration of 2,4-D (mgL−1) after 1h dark adsorption, C t is the concentration of 2,4-D remaining in the solution at irradiation time t (min), and k obs is the observed rate constant (min−1). The k obs was found in the order of 2>5>10>1>0.5>0at%, which was consistent with the conclusion of photocatalytic degradation curves presented in Fig. 6a. The summary of the pseudo-first-order kinetics of the as-prepared samples under visible-light irradiation is shown in Table 1 . 3.5.2 The photocatalytic degradation process of 2,4-D Fig. 7 shows the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D over the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at% under visible-light irradiation. Fig. 7a shows the changes of the HPLC profiles of 2,4-D solution during the photocatalytic process by the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at%. From the figure, it can be seen that the retention time of 2,4-D was about 2.5min. After 30min of visible-light irradiation, the peak intensity corresponding to 2,4-D decreased and there appeared two new peaks at retention times of 2.1 and 2.8min, which corresponded to the formation of chlorohydroquinone (CHQ), and 2,4-diclorophenol (2,4-DCP), respectively. The peak corresponded to 2,4-D almost disappeared approximately at 120min of visible-light irradiation, indicating its total degradation. During the 2,4-D degradation, 2,4-DCP was found to be the major by-product and CHQ was produced as minor by-product. This identification was also consistent with that reported in other studies [22,28]. The photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D under different experimental conditions is shown in Fig. 7b. When the 2,4-D solution without the MoO3/ZnO NR composites was irradiated, or when the solution with the photocatalyts was kept in the dark, only small amounts of 2,4-D were degraded or adsorbed. The extent of degradation of the two samples reached 8.6% and 9.2%, respectively within 120min. However, 99.2% of 2,4-D was degraded after 120min with the MoO3/ZnO NRs prepared at 2at%, which demonstrated higher photocatalytic activity as compared to the pure ZnO NRs under visible-light irradiation. The results suggested that the as-obtained MoO3/ZnO NR composites exhibited high visible-light photocatalytic activity for degradation of 2,4-D. 3.5.3 The effect of the amount of catalyst on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D The effect of the amount of catalyst on the degradation rate of 2,4-D was investigated over the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at% under visible-light irradiation (as recorded in Table 1). When the amount of catalyst at 1.5gL−1, the k obs was 0.0488min−1, which was higher than that at 1.0 and 2.0gL−1. Higher amount of catalyst revealed more availability of total surface area and active sites of the catalyst. A reduction in degradation rate was generally observed at catalyst overdose owing to light scattering by the excess catalyst and reduced the light penetration. It indicated that an optimal amount (1.5gL−1) was chosen for the further studies. 3.5.4 The effect of the initial substrate concentration on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D The effect of the initial concentration of 2,4-D on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D was studied over MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at% under visible-light irradiation. As shown in Table 1, the MoO3/ZnO NRs exhibited higher degradation rate for 20mgL−1 2,4-D solution than for 40 and 60mgL−1 2,4-D solution. Increasing the 2,4-D concentration seems to decrease the availability of active sites for occupation by the 2,4-D, which reduced the photocatalytic activity of the catalyst. Another factor which may be responsible for the drop in photocatalytic activity was the visible-light cannot pass through the 2,4-D solutions due to the light attenuation in higher 2,4-D concentration [2]. Consequently, a low initial concentration of 20mgL−1 should be selected to get an ideal degradation rate. 3.5.5 The effect of the solution pH on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D To study the effect of pH on the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D, one set of photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D over the MoO3/ZnO NR composites prepared at 2at% under different initial pH values is shown in Table 1. The pH of the solution was adjusted using equimolar NaOH or HCl solutions. It can be seen that the increase in degradation rate was observed as pH tends to neutrality. In other words, the highest degradation effect was observed at pH 7.04. In aqueous suspensions, ZnO surface would prefer to remain hydroxylated [29]. The point of zero charge of ZnO and MoO3 are pHpzc 6.8 and pHpzc 8.2. Thus, 2,4-D degradation process proceeded slowly at any pH higher than 6.0. This was perhaps as a result of the shifted of the dissociation equilibrium of 2,4-D in favour of the molecular compound (Eq. (5)). (5) C 8 H 6 ( Cl ) 2 O 3 ⇄ H + OH − C 8 H 5 ( Cl ) 2 O 3 − A decrease in 2,4-D removal rate was observed as pH 7.04 was exceeded. This observation may be attributed to the repulsion of C8H5(Cl)2O3 – by ZnO− as the pK a of 2,4-D (pK a =4.6) and the pzc of ZnO were exceeded. Such repulsion may cause reduced adsorption of substrate and led to low degradation rates. Hence, the catalyst showed highest photocatalytic efficiency when the initial solution pH was 7.04. In summary, the highest k obs of 2,4-D degradation can be obtained by controlling the influencing factors, in which MoO3 loading, initial 2,4-D concentration and solution pH exerted greater effects than the MoO3/ZnO NRs amount. 3.6 Reusability of catalyst Based on the key principles of green chemistry, effective catalysis and the catalytic recovery were crucial to feasibility of the process to reduce organic pollutants from wastewater [30]. Therefore, two criteria were needed to be considered for their possible continuous use in the practical applications: (i) the stability of the catalyst to sustain its high activity over time. To examine the stability of MoO3/ZnO NRs, the catalysts were reused for four times. The results are shown in Fig. 8 . At the first cycle, 2,4-D was completely degraded. The catalytic efficiency of the composite photocatalyst, which was still higher than 90% after being used for four cycles, reduced slowly as the application cycles increased. It can be concluded that the photocatalytic ability of MoO3/ZnO NRs decreased little, if any, because it was very difficult to avoid no any loss of catalyst materials in the experiments. Thus, the reduced catalysis ability may be ascribed to the tiny loss of the photocatalyst. (ii) The ease with which the catalyst could be recycled from solution. In this work, the samples were of 1D nanorods morphology and could be easily separated from the aqueous suspensions by sedimentation, probably due to the large length to diameter ratio of the 1D MoO3/ZnO NRs. The stability of the MoO3/ZnO NRs was further confirmed by XRD pattern and FTIR spectrum of MoO3/ZnO NRs composites after long time irradiation as shown in Fig. 9 . The XRD pattern in Fig. 9a of the used MoO3/ZnO NRs showed that the crystal structure of the composites did not change after the photocatalytic reaction, indicating their high stability and do not photocorrode during the photocatalytic reaction. It can be seen from Fig. 9b that the reaction intermediates and products during photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-D such as CHQ and 2,4-DCP cannot be observed except for the vibration mode of MoO3/ZnO NRs, which revealed that the reaction intermediates and products could diffuse rapidly due to the 1D nanostructure. This was another reason for the excellent photochemical stability of MoO3/ZnO NR composites. 3.7 Postulated photocatalytic mechanism 3.7.1 Photoluminescence (PL) spectra Photoluminescence (PL) is related with the electronic, optical, and photoelectric properties of materials [31]. Especially, PL can provide some essential information connecting to the separation and recombination of photogenerated charge carriers of semiconductors. Herein, PL measurements were used to determine the charge separation behaviours and efficiencies of the as-prepared samples (depicted in Fig. 10 ). From the figure, it can be seen that the PL spectra patterns of all the MoO3/ZnO NR composites recorded in Fig. 10b–f showed dramatic decrease in emission yield as compared to pure ZnO NRs (Fig. 10a). Such a decrease in emission might be attributed to the efficient charge injection process between the ZnO NRs and MoO3 nanoparticles. Additionally, the PL intensity of MoO3/ZnO NRs changed with the altering of MoO3 loading. As for 2at% MoO3/ZnO NRs, the PL spectrum as shown in Fig. 10d was the lowest. Since the PL signal was the result of the recombination of charge carriers, the lower PL intensity showed a lower recombination rate of charge carriers and corresponded to higher photocatalytic activity [18,32]. It implied that 2at% MoO3/ZnO NRs have the lowest charge carriers recombination rate, inferring that the charge carriers have longer lifetime and might form larger amount of active ·OH radicals in the photocatalytic reaction. 3.7.2 Hydroxyl (·OH) radical analysis As literature documented [1,2], photocatalytic mechanism involved a portion of photogenerated electrons and holes reacted with adsorbed O2 and H2O to generate active species such as hydroxyl radicals (·OH) that further participated in the organic pollutant degradation reaction. The ·OH radicals produced in water can be identified by PL or other techniques [33–35]. In this study, the formation of ·OH radicals on the surface of MoO3/ZnO NRs irradiated by visible-light was identified by PL technique with terephthalic acid (TA) as a probe molecule. Fig. 11 displays the PL spectra changes observed during the visible-light irradiation of the pure ZnO NRs as well as the MoO3/ZnO NR composites in the aqueous basic solution of TA (excitation at 315nm). Usually, PL intensity at about 425nm was proportional to the amount of produced ·OH radicals. It can be clearly seen that the amount of ·OH radicals produced on 2at% MoO3/ZnO NRs was larger than that of other samples. This implied that the former has higher photocatalytic activity than the latter, which was also consistent with the results of PL emission spectra in Fig. 10. Moreover, all the MoO3/ZnO NR composites exhibited higher PL intensity than pure ZnO NRs, suggesting that loading of MoO3 on the surface of ZnO NRs was a good route to induce the transfer and separation of the photogenerated charge carriers, which resulted in the increase of ·OH formation. Furthermore, the PL spectra changing with the irradiation time for the case of 2at% MoO3/ZnO NR composites were also carried out (recorded in inset of Fig. 11). A gradual increase in PL intensity was observed with the increase of irradiation time, revealing that the fluorescence came from chemical reactions of TA with ·OH formed during photocatalytic reactions [36,37]. Thus, ·OH experiments further confirmed that ·OH was actually produced and indeed participated in degradation process. Combining our experiment results with the related literature [33], a postulated mechanism for the enhanced photocatalysis of MoO3/ZnO NR composites under visible-light irradiation was showed here. Upon light excitation, electrons from the ZnO NRs and MoO3 may be promoted from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB), leaving behind holes in the VB. As the CB of MoO3 was lower than that of ZnO NRs, the former can be used as a photoelectronic receiver. The photogenerated electrons of the ZnO NRs CB will be transferred to the CB of MoO3 and then converted to active ·OH according to the following steps [26,38,39]: (6) e− +O2 →O2·− (7) O2·− +H+ →HOO· (8) HOO·+H+ +e− →H2O2 (9) H2O2 +e− →·OH+OH− Simultaneously, the holes move in the opposite direction from the electrons, photogenerated holes will be captured within the ZnO NRs and also converted to active ·OH as shown in steps [40–42]: (10) h+ +H2O→·OH+H+ (11) h+ +OH− →·OH Therefore, active ·OH resulted in the degradation of 2,4-D under visible-light using MoO3/ZnO NR composites. Scheme 1 is an illustration of interparticle electron and hole transfer behaviour. Through this way, the photogenerated charge carriers can be separated efficiently and improved the photocatalytic activity of MoO3/ZnO NRs under visible-light irradiation. 4 Conclusions The composite MoO3/ZnO NRs with MoO3 nanoparticles incorporated with ZnO NRs was successfully synthesized by a simple hydrothermal-precipitation method. The structure, morphologies and optical properties of the as-prepared composites were confirmed by XRD, FESEM, HRTEM, EDX, FTIR, UV–vis and PL measurements. The investigation of photocatalytic ability showed that various parameters such as MoO3 content in the catalyst, MoO3/ZnO NRs amount, initial 2,4-D concentration and solution pH exerted their individual influence on the degradation of 2,4-D. The as-prepared MoO3/ZnO NRs could be easily separated and recycled due to their 1D nanostructural property. Moreover, MoO3/ZnO NRs prepared at 2at% displayed the highest photocatalytic activity with k obs of 0.0452min−1 under visible-light irradiation due to the high quantum yield based on the cooperative roles between the bi-components of MoO3 and ZnO NRs as evidenced by their PL spectra and ·OH generation ability. Probably, the strategy presented in this work would provide clues for developing new types of composite photocatalyst for environmental purification. coredata.dc:description: Nanoscaled MoO3 particles loaded on ZnO nanorods (ZnO NRs) were synthesized via a hydrothermal-precipitation method. X-ray diffraction, field emission-scanning electron microscopy, high resolution transmission electron microscopy, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV–vis absorption and photoluminescence studies were used to characterize the structures, morphologies and optical properties of the composites. The results showed that pure orthorhombic phase of α-MoO3 nanoparticles with average sizes of 15–21nm were well dispersed on the surface of ZnO NRs. The MoO3/ZnO NR composites also showed high charge separation efficiency and ·OH generation ability as evidenced by their photoluminescence spectra. The photocatalytic studies revealed that the MoO3/ZnO NRs showed superior visible-light degradation rate for herbicide 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) compared with the pure ZnO NRs. Such enhancement might be attributed to the high separation efficiency of photogenerated electron–hole pairs based on the cooperative roles between bi-components of MoO3 and ZnO NRs. The photocatalytic studies also showed that various parameters such as the MoO3 content in the composite, MoO3/ZnO NRs amount, initial 2,4-D concentration and solution pH exerted their individual influence on the 2,4-D degradation. Moreover, the MoO3/ZnO NRs could be easily recovered and reused due to their one-dimensional nanostructural property.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation on visible-light photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid in the presence of MoO3/ZnO nanorod composites
